name: copper mine operation and beneficiation, sulfide ore | copper concentrate, sulfide ore | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/22712/documentation

"For the mining and beneficiation of copper sulfide ores in Kazhakstan.;Background: Metals are produced as part of a complex, highly interconnected and interdependent system, with many desirable but scarce/critical metals recovered as by-products during the production of one or more ‘host’ metal(s). Copper is one of the world’s major mineral commodities and is mined from heterogeneous sulfide or oxide mineral deposits in countries worldwide. Copper sulfide deposits, such as those of the porphyry or massive sulphide type, contain numerous other valuable minerals, which are desirable to society. Copper is mined & beneficiated to produce a copper sulfide concentrate, as well as other by-product concentrates (e.g. molybdenite), which are sold to smelters. Copper sulfide concentrates are smelted to produce the intermediate product, copper anode. This is then sold to refineries, where it is electrorefined to produce copper cathode, which is sold to fabricators. The by-product of copper electrorefining is anode slime, which contains various important by-product metals (principally gold, silver, selenium & tellurium) and is sold to precious metal recovery plants for further processing to recover the valuable metals. ;Modelling approach: This dataset was created using the life cycle inventory process model described by Classen et al. (2009) and used to generate datasets for ecoinvent v2.1. Typical average ore grades are estimated for each region based on data from Northey et al. (2014), while values for several other key input parameters have been updated since the release of the v2.1 dataset. These include (non-exclusively) the production volumes, beneficiation efficiency (i.e. yield), concentrate grades, anode slime composition (a product of the downstream copper electrorefining processing but that has a direct influence on the properties of exchanges in this dataset), and water outputs. Further information on these changes is provided in the Sampling Procedure comment, as well as the accompanying documentation (see Turner & Hischier, 2020). ;References:;Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.;Northey, S., Mohr, S., Mudd, G. M., Weng, Z., & Giurco, D. (2014). Modelling future copper ore grade decline based on a detailed assessment of copper resources and mining. Resources Conservation and Recycling, 83, 190-201.;Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland."

Construction of mine site (including mill), including site excavation and facility installation.

Site closure; termination of mining and beneficiation activities and the deconstruction of the mine site.

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Production volumes are representative of the situation in 2015 but are considered valid until the end of 2019. Data sources for the inventory model have not been updated since v2.1 (see Classen et al. 2009), but important model parameters that determine input data to the model have been updated to be consistent with the current situation.;References;Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is valid for the whole corresponding region. Some agents used, such as lime and sodium cynaide, originate from datasets value for Switzerland or Europe. Processes such as blasting originate from datasets value for Switzerland or Europe. Exchanges amounts calculated based on country-specific average ore grade (as reported in Northey et al. 2014).;References:;Northey, S., Mohr, S., Mudd, G. M., Weng, Z., & Giurco, D. (2014). Modelling future copper ore grade decline based on a detailed assessment of copper resources and mining. Resources Conservation and Recycling, 83, 190-201.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Based on typical current technology. Mining is done 70% open pit and 30% underground, followed by joint beneficiation of copper and molybdenite trough flotation, where considerable amounts of agents are added. Overburden is disposed separate to sulfidic tailings near the mining site. No dewatering (or other pre-treatment) of the tailings of is assumed as this is considered a treatment activity that occurs only at selective sites and is therefore modelled separately.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: see Geography, Technology and general comments.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
All exchanges to the environment and from the technosphere calculated using the life cycle inventory model presented in Classen et al. (2009) for 'copper, molybdenum & telluride and silver containing byproducts' (ecoinvent v.2.1). All exchange values are calculated as a function of the mass of ore processed, which is itself a function of ore grade. To increase the temporal and geographical representativeness of the inventory, ore grades have been updated here (since v2.1) based on data from sustainability reports published by mining companies operating in the country. Note that, unlike for other regions, data were not available from Northey et al. (2014); hence, data directly from mining companies in KZ were used. The estimated average copper ore grade in Kazakhstan is 1.78%. 

The amounts and composition (exchange properties) of 'copper concentrate, sulfide ore', 'molybdenute concentrate' and 'treatment of sulfidic tailings, from copper mine operation, tailings impoundment' were estimated based on a global material flow analysis of copper production. Key input data to the model include: production volumes of each metal, taken from the USGS Minerals Yearbook 2015; concentration yields (i.e. transfer coefficients for each element from Earth's crust to each product via mining and beneficiation), taken as the arithmetic mean of values reported in the literature; anode slime composition, from which the amounts of silver, gold, tellerium and selenium that are extracted from the Earth's crust during this activity are estimated, taken as the arithmetic mean of values reported in the literature; 'copper concentrate,sulfide ore' grade (26.7% Cu), taken from Delbeke & Rodriguez (2014); 'molybdenite concentrate' composition, taken as the arithmetic mean of values reported in the literature (48% Mo; 3.5% Cu). For more information, please refer to the accompanying documentation. 

References
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Scharnhost, W., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., & Emmenegger, M. F. (2009). Life cycle inventories of metals. Final report, ecoinvent data v2.1, No. 10. Dübendorf, Switzerland.
Delbeke, K., & Rodriguez, P. H. (2014). Copper Concentrates - Environmental and Human Health hazard classification. Application to the assessment of substances “Harmful to the Marine Environment” (HME) as set out under the 2012 Annex V MARPOL Convention amendments. Santiago, Chile.
Northey, S., Mohr, S., Mudd, G. M., Weng, Z., & Giurco, D. (2014). Modelling future copper ore grade decline based on a detailed assessment of copper resources and mining. Resources Conservation and Recycling, 83, 190-201.

exchanges.description: Amount calculated through mass balance of the copper production chain. Source: Turner & Hischier (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland.

exchanges.description:
Amount calculated through mass balance of the copper production chain. Source: Turner, D. A. & Hischier, R. (2020). Life cycle inventories of pyrometallurgical copper production and anode slime processing. Empa, St. Gallen, Switzerland.
The Te amount is based on the estimated amount of anode slime produced in the given region and the average Te content of the anode slime. The Te amount was then adjusted based on the assumption that the regions extract 70% of the global Te that is extracted in copper ores.
